document.title: Looking for a cluster
document.paragraph:
1Looking for a cluster If you know the name of a cluster but not where it is located in the system, there are two ways to find this out:
You can try to find it in the
../../../reference/10_browsing_tools/20_cluster_tool/00_introduction.xml cluster tool by expanding the cluster tree.
In a window where the context tool is independent from the editor, you can type the name of the cluster in
../../../reference/10_browsing_tools/10_address_bars/20_context_tool_address_bar.xml context tool address bar . You may use wildcards ("*" or "?") if you know only a part of the name. You can then locate the cluster in the system by
../../../reference/05_general_interface_description/10_general_interface_mechanisms/10_pick_and_drop.xml picking the cluster stone in the
../../../reference/10_browsing_tools/10_address_bars/20_context_tool_address_bar.xml address bar and dropping it on the
../../../reference/10_browsing_tools/20_cluster_tool/40_locate_command.xml view icon
/images/eiffelstudio/icons/icon_view_small_color.gif of the
../../../reference/10_browsing_tools/20_cluster_tool/00_introduction.xml cluster tool .
